title: Malcolm Changleng
text:
Malcolm Changleng (born 25 April 1970) is a <a href="Scotland">Scottish</a> former professional <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> <a href="referee">referee</a>. He is the <a href="Twin%23Monozygotic%20twins">identical twin</a> brother of fellow referee <a href="David%20Changleng">David Changleng</a>.
Changleng began his rugby career as a player with <a href="Gala%20RFC">Gala RFC</a>, playing at <a href="Fullback%20%28rugby%20union%29">fullback</a> in the team that won the 1999 Scottish Cup, along with Scottish internationals <a href="Gregor%20Townsend">Gregor Townsend</a> and <a href="Chris%20Paterson">Chris Paterson</a>. He also represented the <a href="Border%20Reivers%20%28rugby%20union%29">Scottish Borders</a> in the <a href="1996%E2%80%9397%20Heineken%20Cup">1996–97 Heineken Cup</a>, scoring a <a href="Try%20%28rugby%29">try</a> in a 34–25 defeat at home to <a href="Leinster%20Rugby">Leinster</a> on 26 October 1996.
After retiring as a player, Changleng followed his brother into refereeing. He turned professional in 2002, and refereed his first European match on 17 January 2004, when he took charge of the <a href="European%20Shield">European Shield</a> match between <a href="Rugby%20Viadana">Viadana</a> and <a href="CRC%20Madrid">Madrid</a>. His first <a href="European%20Rugby%20Champions%20Cup">European Rugby Champions Cup</a> match came the following season, when he refereed <a href="Benetton%20Rugby">Benetton Treviso</a>'s 34–0 away win over <a href="CS%20Bourgoin-Jallieu">Bourgoin</a> on 29 October 2004.
On the international scene, Changleng's most prestigious refereeing appointment came on 9 June 2007, when he officiated a match between <a href="South%20Africa%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">South Africa</a> and <a href="Samoa%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Samoa</a>. He also refereed <a href="2007%20Rugby%20World%20Cup%20qualifying">2007 Rugby World Cup qualifying</a> matches in both North America and Europe before being named as one of 13 touch judges for the <a href="2007%20Rugby%20World%20Cup">2007 Rugby World Cup</a> in France, where he was the only Scottish official named.
In January 2008, Changleng retired from professional refereeing in order to spend more time with his family and return to his teaching career at <a href="Galashiels%20Academy">Galashiels Academy</a>.
